VERFORD FARM UNIT |
FORMS MILKING CLASS

Students Rise at 5 for First
Work in College
Barns
Haverford College started a class

These announcements were made today,
with the information that a farm unit had
been formed at fhe Main Line
which will follow the constructive and re-
lief work plans ef the Friends’ Sehoo! It
js against the belicf of the Friends to enter
war to. kill but they are organizing to
give relief and supply food

The organization of the farm unit has
been completed, with Prof. Ro W. Keisey
as chairman, assisted by Herbert (. Baker,
superintendent of the college farm, and Dr

A. H, Wilson and Dt Richard Mott Gum-
mere, of the college faculty, and two un-
dergraduates, F H. Morris, of Kennersville,
NW, C., a senior, and Walter Nevin, of Nar-
berth, a jumor, who were elected this morn.
ing by the student body to serve on the
eommittee

Doctor Gumimere will have permanent
headquarters at the college and will be see-
and business manager The work |

il r eortinue during the summer Tie
farm unit was planned with the assistance
of Dr. J. Russell Smith, of the University of
Pennsylvania, |
The first practical work began this morn. |
!

tng at when students went to the
college barns and took their first le in

milking. A group will do this each morn-
ing
5 o'clock,
“son

Tomorrow afternoon at o'clock son
of the volunteers, of whom there are about
twenty-five, will plow and harrow a set
tion of the campus, They will work on th
until it is completed They will then turn
it over to the Main J.ine Citizens’ Asso
ciation for the committee which Mr Kb. Y¥ i
Hartshorne directs

When they have completed plowing on
the campus they will plow, harrow and |]
@ultivate a 200-acre tract, lent by the col- |
lege to the township committee, situated
near the Merion Golf Club The tract
{in charge of Richard 8S, Dewees, township |
commissioner, and Alfred M Collins, presi- |
dent of the Main Line Citizens’ Associa-
tion.

NEEDLEWORK GUILD
IN ANNUAL CONVENTION

+ ‘ |
Organization Representing 500,- |
000 Women Honors Philadel- |
phians in Election
WED WHEN WAR CALLS YOUNG DOCTOR | WED AS WAR CALLS

Three Philadelphia and five Pennsylvania
Women were honored today by being elected
to offices in the Needlework Guild of Amer-
fea, a National organization with soo,d00
women, which is in its thirty-second annual
convention today and tomorrow at the Cul
tis Building auditorium

Mrs. George Fales Baker, of Bryn Mawt
Was unanimously elected first vice presi
dent, Mrs, O, S. Keely national recording
secretary and Miss Rosamond kK, Bender
national recording retary

Mrs. Levi P. Morton, New York, wa
elected honorary national president; Mrs
Truman H. Newberry, Detroit. national |
president, and the other officers as follows

Second vice president, Mr Robert F. Hard-
ing Fort Wayne, Ind.; third vice president
Mrs. Samuel Semple, Titusville, Pa.; fourth
vice president, Miss Julia M, Wolbert, Ta-
coma, Wash, and Mrs, Heber Smith, Read- |
ing, national treasurer

The founder of the guild, Mre
Stewart, Glen Falls, N. Y., wa
made a plew for work from the

Johan Wood
present and
women for
home defense

“fam as much of a patriot as any one,”
she said “But there are plenty of people
working for the soldiers and the satlors,
and | fear that in the excitement of patri-
Otism the mothers and babies in this coun-

try will be neglected We are working
hard for relief. We have a department
for that, and I am glad of it, but [ hope
that we will continue to increase our work
for the needy.”

A report from the 4380 branches of the
guild showed that 723.929 new garments
had been made and given away last year
This was an increase of 16,575 over the |
Preceding year.

Practical needlework for war purposes
was a leading topic of discussion of the
450 delegates.
After an address of welcome by G. W. B

Hicks, of the Philadelphia Chamber of
Commerce, a picture of Betsy Ross fone
of the original needlework women of th
world,” was presented to the guild by Mi>
Truman HH. Newberry, of Detroit, national
president of the organization Memorial
services were held for Mrs, DP, Edwin
Irving, of this city, national treasurer, who
died last December,

HOTELMEN WILL SAVE
PARINGS OF POTATOES

Will Follow Governor’s Sugges-
tion for Increasing State's
Food Supply

Hotelmen and managers of cafes in Phil-
@deiphia were all of unanimous mind in
Teplying to the suggestion of (Goyernor
Brumbaugh that they save the parings and
éyes of potatoes to be used for planting
There is danger of a potato shortage and |
So he tas-
the Governor is looking ahead,
sued an appeal all through the State, ask- |
ing the restaurant men to help

All Philadelphians who are able to help
in this matter are willing to; they are only
waiting for instructions to what they
should do with the materials they are asked
to save. Some of their comments follow:

J. Miller Frazier,
We are only too glad to help in any way
at all, and, of course, we will do what
Governor Brumbaugh asks.

Bert Crowhurst, Walton—-Governor Brum-
baugh has but to say the word and he may
have anything we have. We are glad to
help along his potato suggestion.

J. C. Bonner, Ritz-Carlton—-We are de-
lighted to follow out the suggestion made by
the Governor, We will start right away.

The same kind of replies came from the
Adelphia, L'Aiglon, Arcadia and all the
other places visited.

GIRL SHORN OF TRESSES;
ACQUAINTANCE ACCUSED

Man Held in $1500 Bail on Charge
Made by Young Victim’s
Little Brother

Pretty Bessie Leichos has had her black
fyesses snipped off, and James Plajeaka, a
former border in the Leichos home at 4
Winter's court, has been charged with the
act. He was held under $1600 bail for
court today by Magistrate Tracy, in the
Eleventh and Winter streets station,

Bessie, Who is seventeen years old, testi-
fied that a man choked her near her home
last Tuesday, snipped off her hair and fled,
leaving the long black braid lying on the
pavement, Her brother Antony, a newsboy,
eleven yeais old, told the Magistrate that
Plajeaka had shown him a knife, saying,
“This is the knife that cut off your sister's

The renowned prelate ta in splendid phys-
jcal health and says mase faithfully each
morning at 7:40 in the chapel of the rectory,

Archbishop Prendergast was born
Clonmel, Ireland, He came to this coun-
try with his parente in 1859.’ He studied
at St, Charles Borromeo Seminary in Over-
brook and was ordained priest in 1865. He
wae an assistant priest at St. Paul's Church
in this city and later served as curate in
Susquehanna Depot, Pa. His first pastor
ate was in Bristol, Pa, at St. Mark's
Church, From Bristol he wae transferred
to Allentown, The Archbishop came to
Philadeiphia in 1884 and was stationed at
St. Malachy’s Church. He was consecrated
auxiliary biehop of this city in 1897 and
was appointed Archbishop in 1911 after the
death of Archbishop Ryan. Ue was vicar
general of the diocese from 1895 to 1897.

You Can Wean ,
Your Baby Safely

These are the questions that
bother you and every other
young mother now.
nurse your baby all summer?
Must you wean him now? Or
can you give the baby some-
thing beside your own milk?

You will be glad to know that
you don’t have to worry about
weaning time—that you can
take your baby through the
dangerous weaning days,
